thread.title: Brexit: What is a People's Vote and how would a second referendum work?

author: Jonathan Walker
title: Brexit: What is a People's Vote and how would a second referendum work?
text:
Who supports a People's Vote?
The People's Vote campaign is an organised campaign led by a pressure group called Open Britain.
To start with, it was supported by a small number of MPs. They include Labour MP Chuka Umunna and Conservative MP Anna Soubry. Read More
But recently, more MPs have been saying they support it. North East MPs include Catherine McKinnell (Lab Newcastle North) and Sedgefield MP Phil Wilson (Lab).
Theresa May says she opposes a People's Vote. Read More
Labour's official policy is to keep the option of supporting a People's Vote "on the table" in some circumstances. How would a referendum work?
It would be a lot like the last referendum. You'd vote in a polling station (a bit like in a general election) and there would probably be TV debates.
What's not clear though is what options would be on the ballot paper.
Possibilities include:
i) Supporting the Government's Brexit deal
ii) Leaving the EU with no Brexit deal
iii) Cancelling Brexit. How the North East voted in the EU Referendum in June 2016
Newcastle: Remain 65,404 (50.7%); Leave 63,598 (49.3%)
Sunderland: Remain 51,930 (38.7%); Leave 82,394 (61.3%)
North Tyneside: Remain 52,873 (46.63%); Leave 60,589 (53.37%)
Gateshead: Remain 44,429 (43.2%); Leave 58,529 (56.8%)
South Tyneside: Remain 30,014 (38%); Leave 49,065 (62%)
Durham: Remain 113,521 (42.5%); Leave 153,877 (57.5%)
Northumberland: Remain 82,022 (46%); Leave 96,699 (54%)
However, it seems like a bad idea to have three different options. It might well mean that none of them get a majority of the votes.
So you might have only two choices. The problem then is, how do you choose which two to include?
It's an awkward issue. Most supporters of a People's Vote have avoided getting into an argument about the options.
It's possible an independent body could make the decision about what the question on the ballot paper should be. Like us on Facebook
